values.description: The joystick is using `/dev/input/js1` on my machine for some reason, but the `joy_dev` argument wasn't exposed by team.launch, so I added it here and pass it to teleop.launch, which already has that argument.

values.description: This pull request adds prefixes to all the links in X1 and X2 robots. The prefix is set to the namespace. This allows TF frames to be published without clashing with each other.
values.title: Add namespace prefix

summary.raw: This pull request adds prefixes to all the links in X1 and X2 robots. The prefix is set to the namespace. This allows TF frames to be published without clashing with each other.

values.description: While testing [this](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/ExampleSetup) tutorial, I noticed that X4 wasn’t successfully registering its communication address in the broker. The broker was up and running but the model wasn’t inserted into the simulation when the registration was being processed. This patch adds some logic to the CommsClient constructor for retrying.
values.title: Retry registrations

summary.raw: While testing [this](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/ExampleSetup) tutorial, I noticed that X4 wasn’t successfully registering its communication address in the broker. The broker was up and running but the model wasn’t inserted into the simulation when the registration was being processed. This patch adds some logic to the CommsClient constructor for retrying.
summary.html: While testing this tutorial, I noticed that X4 wasn’t successfully registering its communication address in the broker. The broker was up and running but the model wasn’t inserted into the simulation when the registration was being processed. This patch adds some logic to the CommsClient constructor for retrying.

values.description:
Added the ability to load X1 with four sensor configurations:

1. 2D short range LIDAR \+ QVGA camera \+ IMU
2. 2D long range LIDAR \+ HD camera \+ IMU
3. 3D medium range LIDAR \+ QVGA camera \+ IMU
4. 3D long range LIDAR \+ HD camera \+ IMU

For testing, use `X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1`, `X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_2`, `X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_3` or `X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_4` environment variables. Here’s an example:

    roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch scenario:=tunnel_practice_2
    X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_3=1 X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1=1 roslaunch subt_example team.launch

I’ve also included its own rviz launch file:

    roslaunch subt_example x1_rviz.launch

It requires a new dependency:

    sudo apt install ros-melodic-velodyne-simulator

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2653585392-x1_hokuyo.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2689884381-x1_mid_lidar.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2922533031-x1_3d_lidar.png)
values.title: Sensor configurations for X1

For testing, use X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1, X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_2, X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_3 or X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_4 environment variables. Here’s an example:

roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch scenario:=tunnel_practice_2

I’ve also included its own rviz launch file:

It requires a new dependency:

values.description:
Added the ability to load X3 with four sensor configurations:

1. QVGA camera \+ IMU
2. HG camera \+ IMU
3. QVGA RGBD camera \+ IMU
4. VGA RGBD camera \+ IMU

For testing, use `X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_1`, `X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_2`, `X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_3` or `X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_4` environment variables. Here’s an example:

    roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch scenario:=tunnel_practice_2
    X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_3=1 X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1=1 X3_SENSOR_CONFIG_3=1 roslaunch subt_example team.launch

I’ve also included two separate rviz launch files:

\(Option 1: X3 equipped with a camera\)

    roslaunch subt_example x3_camera_rviz.launch

\(Option 2: X3 equipped with a depth camera\)

    roslaunch subt_example x3_rgbd_rviz.launch

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3201157895-x3_camera.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1332165270-x3_rgbd.png)
_Note: This pull request is built atop of pull request #62, which should be merged first._

values.description:
The X1 robot is not turning very well, but I think we can fix it by allowing some wheel slip in the lateral direction. This pull request fixes the friction direction (which is relative to the collision) so that it is parallel to the joint axis. It then adds a small amount of wheel slip in that same direction (parallel to the joint axis / lateral to the wheels) that allows some slip during skid-steer turning.

There is a drawback to this change if you are parked sideways on a slope, the robot will slowly slide down at a steady rate. A better fix would be to use the WheelSlipPlugin in the following gazebo pull request, but it is not merged or released yet:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2950/adding-wheelslipplugin-for-adding-wheel/diff
values.title: Improve X1 turning dynamics

summary.raw:
The X1 robot is not turning very well, but I think we can fix it by allowing some wheel slip in the lateral direction. This pull request fixes the friction direction (which is relative to the collision) so that it is parallel to the joint axis. It then adds a small amount of wheel slip in that same direction (parallel to the joint axis / lateral to the wheels) that allows some slip during skid-steer turning.

There is a drawback to this change if you are parked sideways on a slope, the robot will slowly slide down at a steady rate. A better fix would be to use the WheelSlipPlugin in the following gazebo pull request, but it is not merged or released yet:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2950/adding-wheelslipplugin-for-adding-wheel/diff
summary.html:
The X1 robot is not turning very well, but I think we can fix it by allowing some wheel slip in the lateral direction. This pull request fixes the friction direction (which is relative to the collision) so that it is parallel to the joint axis. It then adds a small amount of wheel slip in that same direction (parallel to the joint axis / lateral to the wheels) that allows some slip during skid-steer turning.

There is a drawback to this change if you are parked sideways on a slope, the robot will slowly slide down at a steady rate. A better fix would be to use the WheelSlipPlugin in the following gazebo pull request, but it is not merged or released yet:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2950/adding-wheelslipplugin-for-adding-wheel/diff

values.description:
Slightly slower robots as requested by DARPA.

Bonus: I swapped the propeller colors in X3, to be consistent with X4. Both drones have now the red propellers pointing in the `+X` axis.

_~~Note: Please, review pull request #71 first.~~_
values.title: New robot specs

summary.raw:
Slightly slower robots as requested by DARPA.

Bonus: I swapped the propeller colors in X3, to be consistent with X4. Both drones have now the red propellers pointing in the `+X` axis.

_~~Note: Please, review pull request #71 first.~~_
summary.html:
Slightly slower robots as requested by DARPA.

Bonus: I swapped the propeller colors in X3, to be consistent with X4. Both drones have now the red propellers pointing in the +X axis.

Note: Please, review pull request #71 first.

values.description:
that were generated in our code. This is a first pass, the intent isn’t to remove all warning messages.

E.g.:

    inconsistent namespace redefinitions for xmlns:xacro:
     old: http://www.ros.org/wiki/xacro
     new: http://ros.org/wiki/xacro (/home/developer/subt_ws/install/share/x2_description/urdf/laser_mount.urdf.xacro)
    
    xacro: in-order processing became default in ROS Melodic. You can drop the option.

    [ INFO] [1537910745.894328595, 10.758000000]: Velodyne laser plugin missing <max_range>, defaults to infinity
    [ INFO] [1537910745.894342353, 10.758000000]: Velodyne laser plugin missing <gaussianNoise>, defaults to 0.0

values.description:
The teams need to report the artifact type, besides its pose. The scoring logic has been updated. Now, when an artifact is reported, we look for the closest object to the one reported by the team that matches the same type.

[Wiki updated](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/commits/d510f7e06367d19eb91c99e1a74eb7d0d35fb500).
values.title: Report artifact type

[Wiki updated](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/commits/d510f7e06367d19eb91c99e1a74eb7d0d35fb500).
summary.html:
The teams need to report the artifact type, besides its pose. The scoring logic has been updated. Now, when an artifact is reported, we look for the closest object to the one reported by the team that matches the same type.

values.description: This is a test for the `WindPlugin` that adds wind parameters from the [gazebo wind example](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/f4e51e8f64001beda70615ab8982a7d5a4e65b18/worlds/wind_demo.world?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#wind_demo.world-321:353) to practice_tunnel1 and enables wind for `X1` and `X3` models. It is most noticeable for the drones, which drift with the wind when flying, though they seem to lock in place after a few seconds without any servo commands.
values.title: WindPlugin test

summary.raw: This is a test for the `WindPlugin` that adds wind parameters from the [gazebo wind example](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/f4e51e8f64001beda70615ab8982a7d5a4e65b18/worlds/wind_demo.world?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#wind_demo.world-321:353) to practice_tunnel1 and enables wind for `X1` and `X3` models. It is most noticeable for the drones, which drift with the wind when flying, though they seem to lock in place after a few seconds without any servo commands.
summary.html: This is a test for the WindPlugin that adds wind parameters from the gazebo wind example to practice_tunnel1 and enables wind for X1 and X3 models. It is most noticeable for the drones, which drift with the wind when flying, though they seem to lock in place after a few seconds without any servo commands.

values.description:
When the comms model is working in simple mode**™**, all robots are considered neighbors and all messages will be delivered to their destinations.

The simple comms model can be enabled via the ROS parameter server \(_/subt/comms/simple\_mode_\).

For testing:

1\. Edit `subt_gazebo/worlds/tunnel_practice_1.world` and reduce the maximum comms distance to 1 meter:

    <!-- The SubT comms broker plugin -->
        <plugin name="comms_broker_plugin" filename="libCommsBrokerPlugin.so">
          <comms_model>
            <neighbor_distance_min>0.0</neighbor_distance_min>
            <neighbor_distance_max>1.0</neighbor_distance_max>
            <comms_distance_min>0.0</comms_distance_min>
            <comms_distance_max>1.0</comms_distance_max>
            <comms_drop_probability_min>0.0</comms_drop_probability_min>
            <comms_drop_probability_max>0.0</comms_drop_probability_max>
            <comms_outage_probability>0.0</comms_outage_probability>
            <comms_outage_duration_min>0.0</comms_outage_duration_min>
            <comms_outage_duration_max>10.0</comms_outage_duration_max>
          </comms_model>
        </plugin>

2\. Compile and install as usual:

    catkin_make install

3\. Launch the simulation:

    roslaunch subt_gazebo quickstart.launch

4\. Press the left arrows of the joystick and verity that the LEDs aren’t flashing \(only the LED of the sender robot should flash\).

5\. Enable the simple mode:

    rosparam set /subt/comms/simple_mode true

6\. Repeat the step \(4\) and you should observe the LED’s flashing indicating that the destination robot is receiving messages.

‌

I’ll update the documentation when this PR is merged.
values.title: Simple mode comms

summary.raw:
When the comms model is working in simple mode**™**, all robots are considered neighbors and all messages will be delivered to their destinations.

The simple comms model can be enabled via the ROS parameter server \(_/subt/comms/simple\_mode_\).

For testing:

1\. Edit `subt_gazebo/worlds/tunnel_practice_1.world` and reduce the maximum comms distance to 1 meter:

    <!-- The SubT comms broker plugin -->
        <plugin name="comms_broker_plugin" filename="libCommsBrokerPlugin.so">
          <comms_model>
            <neighbor_distance_min>0.0</neighbor_distance_min>
            <neighbor_distance_max>1.0</neighbor_distance_max>
            <comms_distance_min>0.0</comms_distance_min>
            <comms_distance_max>1.0</comms_distance_max>
            <comms_drop_probability_min>0.0</comms_drop_probability_min>
            <comms_drop_probability_max>0.0</comms_drop_probability_max>
            <comms_outage_probability>0.0</comms_outage_probability>
            <comms_outage_duration_min>0.0</comms_outage_duration_min>
            <comms_outage_duration_max>10.0</comms_outage_duration_max>
          </comms_model>
        </plugin>

2\. Compile and install as usual:

    catkin_make install

3\. Launch the simulation:

    roslaunch subt_gazebo quickstart.launch

4\. Press the left arrows of the joystick and verity that the LEDs aren’t flashing \(only the LED of the sender robot should flash\).

5\. Enable the simple mode:

    rosparam set /subt/comms/simple_mode true

6\. Repeat the step \(4\) and you should observe the LED’s flashing indicating that the destination robot is receiving messages.

‌

I’ll update the documentation when this PR is merged.
summary.html:
When the comms model is working in simple mode™, all robots are considered neighbors and all messages will be delivered to their destinations.

The simple comms model can be enabled via the ROS parameter server (/subt/comms/simple_mode).

For testing:

1. Edit subt_gazebo/worlds/tunnel_practice_1.world and reduce the maximum comms distance to 1 meter:

<!-- The SubT comms broker plugin -->
    <plugin name="comms_broker_plugin" filename="libCommsBrokerPlugin.so">
      <comms_model>
        <neighbor_distance_min>0.0</neighbor_distance_min>
        <neighbor_distance_max>1.0</neighbor_distance_max>
        <comms_distance_min>0.0</comms_distance_min>
        <comms_distance_max>1.0</comms_distance_max>
        <comms_drop_probability_min>0.0</comms_drop_probability_min>
        <comms_drop_probability_max>0.0</comms_drop_probability_max>
        <comms_outage_probability>0.0</comms_outage_probability>
        <comms_outage_duration_min>0.0</comms_outage_duration_min>
        <comms_outage_duration_max>10.0</comms_outage_duration_max>
      </comms_model>
    </plugin>

2. Compile and install as usual:

catkin_make install

3. Launch the simulation:

roslaunch subt_gazebo quickstart.launch

4. Press the left arrows of the joystick and verity that the LEDs aren’t flashing (only the LED of the sender robot should flash).

5. Enable the simple mode:

rosparam set /subt/comms/simple_mode true

6. Repeat the step (4) and you should observe the LED’s flashing indicating that the destination robot is receiving messages.

‌

I’ll update the documentation when this PR is merged.

values.description:
JointMotionTimerPlugin: track the time that robot is in motion

This plugin counts the time during which any of a robot's joint velocities exceed a threshold. This will be useful for an upcoming simple battery model that limits the operating time of a robot.

The plugin is added to the x1, x2, x3 and x4 models as examples. The joints to monitor can be specified as all with an `<all_joints/>` tag or individually with joint names inside `<joint>` tags.

The elapsed time is published under namespaced ignition transport topics:

* `/X3/elapsed_time` publishes the elapsed time at every timestep
* `/X3/elapsed_time_updates` publishes the elapsed time only while the robot is moving and the time is incrementing. To view:

~~~
ign topic -e -t /X3/elapsed_time -d 1
ign topic -e -t /X3/elapsed_time_updates
~~~
values.title: JointMotionTimerPlugin: track the time that robot is in motion

The elapsed time is published under namespaced ignition transport topics:

* `/X3/elapsed_time` publishes the elapsed time at every timestep
* `/X3/elapsed_time_updates` publishes the elapsed time only while the robot is moving and the time is incrementing. To view:

~~~

~~~

JointMotionTimerPlugin: track the time that robot is in motion

This plugin counts the time during which any of a robot's joint velocities exceed a threshold. This will be useful for an upcoming simple battery model that limits the operating time of a robot.

The plugin is added to the x1, x2, x3 and x4 models as examples. The joints to monitor can be specified as all with an <all_joints/> tag or individually with joint names inside <joint> tags.

The elapsed time is published under namespaced ignition transport topics:

  • /X3/elapsed_time publishes the elapsed time at every timestep
  • /X3/elapsed_time_updates publishes the elapsed time only while the robot is moving and the time is incrementing. To view:
ign topic -e -t /X3/elapsed_time -d 1
ign topic -e -t /X3/elapsed_time_updates

values.description:
Before this pull request, the artifacts were reported using a special ROS service. Now, the teams report the artifacts via the regular comms. Highlights:

‌

* For convenience, I've added a new function `SendToBaseStation(...)` to report artifacts.
* `SendToBaseStation(...)` sends the artifact to a base station model, which is using the regular comms to receive messages. @ColeOSRF is working on a nicer base station model. ~~I’ll update the mesh when ready~~ . Mesh updated.
* A new protobuf artifact message has been created. The teams need to populate this message before reporting the artifact.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3949098684-base_station.png)
‌

**Reminder**: Update documentation when this pull request is merged.
values.title: Report artifacts via regular comms

summary.raw:
Before this pull request, the artifacts were reported using a special ROS service. Now, the teams report the artifacts via the regular comms. Highlights:

‌

* For convenience, I've added a new function `SendToBaseStation(...)` to report artifacts.
* `SendToBaseStation(...)` sends the artifact to a base station model, which is using the regular comms to receive messages. @ColeOSRF is working on a nicer base station model. ~~I’ll update the mesh when ready~~ . Mesh updated.
* A new protobuf artifact message has been created. The teams need to populate this message before reporting the artifact.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3949098684-base_station.png)
‌

**Reminder**: Update documentation when this pull request is merged.
summary.html:
Before this pull request, the artifacts were reported using a special ROS service. Now, the teams report the artifacts via the regular comms. Highlights:

‌

  • For convenience, I've added a new function SendToBaseStation(...) to report artifacts.
  • SendToBaseStation(...) sends the artifact to a base station model, which is using the regular comms to receive messages. @ColeOSRF is working on a nicer base station model. I’ll update the mesh when ready . Mesh updated.
  • A new protobuf artifact message has been created. The teams need to populate this message before reporting the artifact.

‌

Reminder: Update documentation when this pull request is merged.

values.description:
This adds `MotionTimerDetachPlugin`, which is derived from `JointMotionTimerPlugin` and disables a robot by detaching joints after a specified amount of time in motion. The default time limit is 20 minutes. To test, apply the following patch to `x2_description` that reduces the time limit to 10 seconds:

~~~
diff -r 915a8a2df644 x2_description/urdf/x2.gazebo
--- a/x2_description/urdf/x2.gazebo     Fri Oct 26 17:31:36 2018 -0700
+++ b/x2_description/urdf/x2.gazebo     Fri Oct 26 17:33:15 2018 -0700
@@ -26,7 +26,8 @@
   </gazebo>
 
   <gazebo>
-    <plugin name="joint_motion_timer" filename="libJointMotionTimerPlugin.so">
+    <plugin name="joint_motion_timer" filename="libMotionTimerDetachPlugin.so">
+      <detach_time_limit>10</detach_time_limit>
       <joint>front_left_wheel</joint>
       <joint>front_right_wheel</joint>
       <joint>rear_left_wheel</joint>
~~~

While driving, you can echo the following topic to keep track of the time, then watch its wheels fall off after 10 seconds:

~~~
ign topic -e -t /X2/elapsed_time_updates
~~~

This makes some slight modifications to `JointMotionTimerPlugin`:

* Add accessors for ElapsedTime and Joints in JointMotionTimerPlugin so derived plugins can access that data

* use new Joints function in OnUpdate

I also exposed an additional debug parameter in competition.launch, which is unrelated but useful.

This would be even better with one of the drones, but one of the plugins in `rotors_gazebo` seg-faults after detaching joints that it is trying to use.
values.title: MotionTimerDetachPlugin: use JointMotionTimerPlugin to disable robot after time limit

values.description:
This adds logging to the GameLogicPlugin and a placeholder for the tunnel qualifcation world.

@scpeters: You can overwrite the tunnel qualification world file.  The key bit to include in your qual world is:

```
     <logging>
       <filename_prefix>subt_tunnel_qual</filename_prefix>
     </logging>
```
inside the GameLogicPlugin.

## Testing

Instructions are here: #!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/qual

To increase the score in the subt log file (which will only work while pull request #85 is NOT merged):

1. Drive a vehicle over the tunnel entrance.

2. `rosservice call /subt/artifacts/new '{pose:{pose:{position:{x: 140, y: 35, z: -20}}}, type: 0}'`

values.description:
We are in the process of expressing the communication connectivity via a graph. This pull request creates the in-memory graph from a graph expressed in DOT.

[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOT\_\(graph\_description\_language\)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOT_(graph_description_language))

values.description:
We want to specify all the artifact poses reported by the teams relative to an artifact origin. This origin will be a fiducial located in the staging area. This pull request:

* Updates the scoring function to receive poses relative to the artifact origin.
* Creates a template for the fiducial model \(for now, just a box\).

‌

~~Note: Do not merge until we integrate the apriltag.~~
values.title: Artifacts relative to some artifact origin

values.description:
Several changes are made to tunnel_qual.world in pull request #91, and this propagates those changes to the `tile_tsv.py` script used to generate that world. The key things are the changes to tunnel_qual.world (restoring xml comment and removing  duct models), and over 300 lines are removed from `tile_tsv.py`. The world file can be regenerated using the command in the xml comment block, and the only lines that will need to be changed are the manual pose updates to the artifacts and tunnel blocker models.

* c148ec4: the world name was changed from `default` to `tunnel_qual`, so add `--world-name` arg to tile_tsv.py and restore xml comment block in tunnel_qual.world

* 971dac5: remove duct models from tsv file instead of commenting them out

* f3b9d81: tile_tsv.py: include tunnel_staging_area model
values.title: staging: use tunnel_staging_area in tile_tsv.py -> pull request #91

The world file can be regenerated using the command in the xml comment block, and the only lines that will need to be changed are the manual pose updates to the artifacts and tunnel blocker models.

Several changes are made to tunnel_qual.world in pull request #91, and this propagates those changes to the tile_tsv.py script used to generate that world. The key things are the changes to tunnel_qual.world (restoring xml comment and removing duct models), and over 300 lines are removed from tile_tsv.py.   • f3b9d81: tile_tsv.py: include tunnel_staging_area model

values.description:
**Motivation**: Before this pull request, one of the parameters of the communication model is distance between source and destination. For SubT, distance is not very appropriate because source and destination could be very close but with a thick wall in between. Similarly, source and destination could be far but within line of sight across a straight section of a tunnel. This pull request introduces a new replacement for distance: connectivity cost.

**Changes to world files**: After this pull request, a SubT world requires three different files:

* <SCENARIO>.world: The regular Gazebo world file. Nothing changes here.
* <SCENARIO>.dot: This text file captures the topological map of the scenario. Each section of the scenario \(e.g.: a tunnel tile, the staging area\) is a vertex of a graph and all pairs of sections physically connected in the world are connected with an edge in the graph. Additionally, vertices capture the model type and model name in case is relevant for the future.
* <SCENARIO>.dat: This binary file is a look-up-table used by the communication model. The content of this file is a sequence of tuples with the format `<int32_t, int32_t, int32_t, uint64_t>`. The first three elements represent a 3D point and the last element is the Id of the vertex associated to the model that surrounds the previous point.

**Changes to the communication model:** After this pull request, the communication model loads the `.dat` and `.dot` files associated to the current Gazebo world. The `.dot` file is used to create an in-memory graph. We run `Dijkstra` on this graph to get the cost of traversing any pair of vertices. The `.dat` file is used to convert a 3D point to the vertex Id where the point is located. This will be relevant when we have two robots located in two 3D coordinates of the world. We need to know which vertices correspond to those two points. When we have the two vertex Ids, we can use the information that we got after running `Dijkstra` to get the associated cost of the path connecting the two robots. The SubT message is discarded if the cost is higher than a given threshold. This threshold is a new parameter of the communication model named `comms_cost_max`.

**How are the costs being assigned to each edge in the graph?** Manually and based on the next heuristic:

* Straight section <-> straight section:`1`
* Straight section <-> non-straight section:`3`
* Non-straight section <-> non-straight section:`6`

**How do I \[re\]generate a** `.dat` **file?** Let's use an example for generating `tunnel_practice_1.dat`:

    roslaunch subt_gazebo visibility.launch scenario:=tunnel_practice_1

You don't need to do this step unless you create a custom world file or modify an existing one because we are committing the `.dat` files.

**Why are we committing the .dat \(binary\) files into the repository?** We considered a couple of options, here’s one:

* Launch the visibility.launch file when running the regular quickstart.launch . This was a promising idea but launch files are not enough to implement the logic that we want. We want to launch the visibility.launch first, and then, when the `.dat` file has been generated launch the quickstart.launch . We might use scripts instead, but given the different set of launch files that we have, it will complicate things unnecessary. The solution of checking in these `.dat` files is very simple \(although I agree that not super elegant\).

**Developer bonus:** I wouldn’t officially advertise it but there’s a service available \(only if you’re in the same machine as Gazebo\)  to display all the areas of the world that are visible from the perspective of one robot. It uses Gazebo markers but it slows down gzclient a lot given the amount of markers published. You can type the following command from the console:

    ign service -s /subt/comms_model/visualize --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean  --timeout 60000 --req 'data: "X1"'

Feel free to replace `X1` with the name of the robot you want to check.
values.title: Communication model based on graph cost

summary.raw:
**Motivation**: Before this pull request, one of the parameters of the communication model is distance between source and destination. For SubT, distance is not very appropriate because source and destination could be very close but with a thick wall in between. Similarly, source and destination could be far but within line of sight across a straight section of a tunnel. This pull request introduces a new replacement for distance: connectivity cost.

**Changes to world files**: After this pull request, a SubT world requires three different files:

* <SCENARIO>.world: The regular Gazebo world file. Nothing changes here.
* <SCENARIO>.dot: This text file captures the topological map of the scenario. Each section of the scenario \(e.g.: a tunnel tile, the staging area\) is a vertex of a graph and all pairs of sections physically connected in the world are connected with an edge in the graph. Additionally, vertices capture the model type and model name in case is relevant for the future.
* <SCENARIO>.dat: This binary file is a look-up-table used by the communication model. The content of this file is a sequence of tuples with the format `<int32_t, int32_t, int32_t, uint64_t>`. The first three elements represent a 3D point and the last element is the Id of the vertex associated to the model that surrounds the previous point.

**Changes to the communication model:** After this pull request, the communication model loads the `.dat` and `.dot` files associated to the current Gazebo world. The `.dot` file is used to create an in-memory graph. We run `Dijkstra` on this graph to get the cost of traversing any pair of vertices. The `.dat` file is used to convert a 3D point to the vertex Id where the point is located. This will be relevant when we have two robots located in two 3D coordinates of the world. We need to know which vertices correspond to those two points. When we have the two vertex Ids, we can use the information that we got after running `Dijkstra` to get the associated cost of the path connecting the two robots. The SubT message is discarded if the cost is higher than a given threshold. This threshold is a new parameter of the communication model named `comms_cost_max`.

**How are the costs being assigned to each edge in the graph?** Manually and based on the next heuristic:

* Straight section <-> straight section:`1`
* Straight section <-> non-straight section:`3`
* Non-straight section <-> non-straight section:`6`

**How do I \[re\]generate a** `.dat` **file?** Let's use an example for generating `tunnel_practice_1.dat`:

    roslaunch subt_gazebo visibility.launch scenario:=tunnel_practice_1

You don't need to do this step unless you create a custom world file or modify an existing one because we are committing the `.dat` files.

**Why are we committing the .dat \(binary\) files into the repository?** We considered a couple of options, here’s one:

* Launch the visibility.launch file when running the regular quickstart.launch . This was a promising idea but launch files are not enough to implement the logic that we want. We want to launch the visibility.launch first, and then, when the `.dat` file has been generated launch the quickstart.launch . We might use scripts instead, but given the different set of launch files that we have, it will complicate things unnecessary. The solution of checking in these `.dat` files is very simple \(although I agree that not super elegant\).

**Developer bonus:** I wouldn’t officially advertise it but there’s a service available \(only if you’re in the same machine as Gazebo\)  to display all the areas of the world that are visible from the perspective of one robot. It uses Gazebo markers but it slows down gzclient a lot given the amount of markers published. You can type the following command from the console:

    ign service -s /subt/comms_model/visualize --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean  --timeout 60000 --req 'data: "X1"'

Feel free to replace `X1` with the name of the robot you want to check.
summary.html:
Motivation: Before this pull request, one of the parameters of the communication model is distance between source and destination. For SubT, distance is not very appropriate because source and destination could be very close but with a thick wall in between. Similarly, source and destination could be far but within line of sight across a straight section of a tunnel. This pull request introduces a new replacement for distance: connectivity cost.

Changes to world files: After this pull request, a SubT world requires three different files:

  • <SCENARIO>.world: The regular Gazebo world file. Nothing changes here.
  • <SCENARIO>.dot: This text file captures the topological map of the scenario. Each section of the scenario (e.g.: a tunnel tile, the staging area) is a vertex of a graph and all pairs of sections physically connected in the world are connected with an edge in the graph. Additionally, vertices capture the model type and model name in case is relevant for the future.
  • <SCENARIO>.dat: This binary file is a look-up-table used by the communication model. The content of this file is a sequence of tuples with the format <int32_t, int32_t, int32_t, uint64_t>. The first three elements represent a 3D point and the last element is the Id of the vertex associated to the model that surrounds the previous point.

Changes to the communication model: After this pull request, the communication model loads the .dat and .dot files associated to the current Gazebo world. The .dot file is used to create an in-memory graph. We run Dijkstra on this graph to get the cost of traversing any pair of vertices. The .dat file is used to convert a 3D point to the vertex Id where the point is located. This will be relevant when we have two robots located in two 3D coordinates of the world. We need to know which vertices correspond to those two points. When we have the two vertex Ids, we can use the information that we got after running Dijkstra to get the associated cost of the path connecting the two robots. The SubT message is discarded if the cost is higher than a given threshold. This threshold is a new parameter of the communication model named comms_cost_max.

How are the costs being assigned to each edge in the graph? Manually and based on the next heuristic:

  • Straight section <-> straight section:1
  • Straight section <-> non-straight section:3
  • Non-straight section <-> non-straight section:6

How do I [re]generate a .dat file? Let's use an example for generating tunnel_practice_1.dat:

roslaunch subt_gazebo visibility.launch scenario:=tunnel_practice_1

You don't need to do this step unless you create a custom world file or modify an existing one because we are committing the .dat files.

Why are we committing the .dat (binary) files into the repository? We considered a couple of options, here’s one:

  • Launch the visibility.launch file when running the regular quickstart.launch . This was a promising idea but launch files are not enough to implement the logic that we want. We want to launch the visibility.launch first, and then, when the .dat file has been generated launch the quickstart.launch . We might use scripts instead, but given the different set of launch files that we have, it will complicate things unnecessary. The solution of checking in these .dat files is very simple (although I agree that not super elegant).

Developer bonus: I wouldn’t officially advertise it but there’s a service available (only if you’re in the same machine as Gazebo) to display all the areas of the world that are visible from the perspective of one robot. It uses Gazebo markers but it slows down gzclient a lot given the amount of markers published. You can type the following command from the console:

ign service -s /subt/comms_model/visualize --reqtype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --reptype ignition.msgs.Boolean  --timeout 60000 --req 'data: "X1"'

Feel free to replace X1 with the name of the robot you want to check.
